wp:Content.noNote: NOTE To enable the Cap Bank Control features of Yukon, you must purchase the Cap Control module. For more information about this module, contact a Cannon Technologies sales representative.
wp:Content.boBody: Web-based capacitor control allows you to access your capacitor control system without having to install a software client on your computer.

wp:GotoLink.liLink: "2.12. Viewing Cap Bank Moves" on page 71

wp:Content.boBody: To access the Web-based capacitor control client:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Start Internet Explorer and enter the name or IP address of the Yukon Web server followed by the port number, which is 8080 by default.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter the username and password of a login that has privileges to access the Web-based capacitor control client.
Click Submit to log into the Web-based capacitor control client.
wp:Content.boBody: To configure which features are accessible to a user of the Capacitor Control application, edit the Login Group that is assigned to the Login of the user. For more information on editing a login group, refer to Yukon Administrator's Guide.
For example, the following login group controls which Capacitor Control features are accessible to a login assigned to this login group.
The Capacitor Control role properties are described below:
wp:Content.buBullet: Administrator - To allow the Capacitor Control administration role properties to be changed, select this check box.
wp:Content.d1Dash1: Access - To enable access to the Capacitor Control application, enter a value of true. Default is false.
Allow Control - To disable local and field controls from within the Capacitor Control application, enter a value of false. Default is true.
cap_control_interface - To change the interface to the optional mapping system, edit the value in the properties area. Default is amfm.
CBC Refresh Rate - To change how often the Capacitor Control application reloads data, edit the value in the properties area. Default is 60 seconds.
cbc_allow_ovuv - To enable OverVoltage and UnderVoltage control of capacitor banks, enter a value of true. Default is false.
cbc_creation_name - To change the text that is added to the name of a CBC when it is created, edit the value in the properties area. Default is CBC%PAOName%.
Database Editing - To enable editing or viewing of the Capacitor Control database, enter a value of true. Default is false.
Hide Graphs - To disable access to graphs within the Capacitor Control application, enter a value of true. Default is false.
Hide One-Lines - To disable access to one-line diagrams within the Capacitor Control application, enter a value of true. Default is false.
Hide Reports - To disable access to reports within the Capacitor Control application, enter a value of true. Default is false.
pfactor_decimal_places - To change the number of decimal places displayed for real values of Power Factor, edit the value in the properties area. Default is 1.
Show Cap Bank Add Info - To display the Additional Info tab for capacitor banks within the Capacitor Control application, enter a value of true. Default is false.
Show Flip Command - To display the flip command for the CBC 7010, CBC 7011, or CBC 7012, enter a value of true. Default is false.
wp:Content.buBullet: Cap Bank Display - To change the display settings for Cap Bank information in a one-line diagram, select this check box.
wp:Content.d1Dash1: Bank Size - To prevent the size of the cap bank from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
CBC Name - To prevent the name of the CBC from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Total Op Count - To prevent the total cap bank operation count from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
wp:Content.buBullet: Feeder Display- To change the display settings for Feeder information in a one-line diagram, select this check box.
wp:Content.d1Dash1: Daily Op Count - To prevent the daily cap bank operation count and maximum daily cap bank operations limit from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
kVAR - To prevent the feeder kVAR value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Power Factor - To prevent the feeder Power Factor value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Volts - To prevent the feeder Volts value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Watts - To prevent the feeder Watts value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
wp:Content.buBullet: Substation Display- To change the display settings for Substation Bus information in a one-line diagram, select this check box.
wp:Content.d1Dash1: Daily Op Count - To prevent the daily cap bank operation count from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Estimated kVAR - To prevent the estimated kVAR value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Estimated Power Factor - To prevent the estimated Power Factor value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
kVAR - To prevent the substation bus kVAR value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Max Op Count - To prevent the maximum daily cap bank operations limit from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Power Factor - To prevent the substation bus Power Factor value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Target - To prevent the substation bus target kVAR or Power Factor value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Volts - To prevent the substation bus Volts value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
Watts - To prevent the substation bus Watts value from appearing in a one-line diagram, enter a value of false. Default is true.
wp:Content.boBody: The first page that appears after logging in is the Substation Areas page, which displays information about the substation areas defined in the system.

The Substation Areas page displays the following information:
Table 2.1 Substation Area Information
Column
Meaning
Area Name
Name of the geographical area of the substation bus.
State
Operational status of the substation area.
Setup
Number of substations with the substation area.
Available kVARs
Total size of all the cap banks within the substation bus that are enabled and available for control.
Disabled kVARs
Total size of all the cap banks within the substation area that are disabled and not available for control.
Closed kVARs
kVAR reading of closed capacitor banks.
Tripped kVARs
kVAR reading of tripped capacitor banks.
PFactor / Est.
PFactor is the current power factor on the substation bus.
Est. is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were closed.

If you click the + next to the name of a substation area (e.g. Southern Area), the substation bus(es) within a substation area are displayed. In addition, the number of feeders and capacitor banks assigned to each substation bus are displayed.
System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value or clicking the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Confirm Area - confirms that the status of each cap bank within the substation area matches the status stored in the Yukon database. For example, if the cap bank status is open, the system sends an open command to the cap bank controller.
Disable Area/Enable Area - disables or enables the substation area.
wp:Content.boBody: To display detailed information about the substation bus(es) within a substation area, click on the name of the substation area (e.g. Southern Area) to display the Substation Buses In Area page.

The Substation Buses In Area page displays the following information:
Table 2.2 Substation Bus Information
Column
Meaning
Sub Name
Name of the substation bus. If a (V) appear next to the name, this means that the substation bus is currently being used in a verification schedule.
State
Operational status of the substation bus. The substation bus is disabled when a verification command is running. When the verification command completes, the substation bus is reneabled.
Target
If the control algorithm is kVAR, this is the target VAR range.
If the control algorithm is Power Factor, this is the target power factor.
If the control algorithm is Multi Volt, Volts, or Multi Volt VAR, this is the target voltage range.
Available kVARs
Total size of all the cap banks within the substation area that are disabled and not available for control.
Disabled kVARs
Total size of all the cap banks within the substation area that are disabled and not available for control.
Closed kVARs
kVAR reading of closed capacitor banks.
Tripped kVARs
kVAR reading of tripped capacitor banks.
VAR Load / Est.
VAR Load is the current VAR value on the substation bus. Est. is an estimate of what the VAR Load would be if no cap banks were on (closed). 1
Date/Time
Date and time of the last substation bus data received.
PFactor / Est.
PFactor is the current power factor on the substation bus.
Est. is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were on (closed).
Watts/Volts
Watts displays the wattage reading of the substation bus.a
Volts displays the voltage reading of the substation bus.a
Daily / Max Ops
Daily is the daily total operation count for all of the cap banks on the substation bus.
Max Ops is a user-defined maximum number of daily cap bank operations.
1If the value is followed by a red (*), the quality of the value is considered not normal. The Cap Control application ignores this value if the Cap Control Ignore Not Normal master config parameter is set to true. By default, this parameter is set to false and the Cap Control application accepts values even if the quality is not normal.
System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value or clicking the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Confirm Sub - confirms that the status of each cap bank on the substation bus matches the status stored in the Yukon database. For example, if the cap bank status is open, the system sends an open command to the cap bank controller.
Disable Sub/Enable Sub - disables or enables the selected substation bus.

Reset Op Counts - resets the daily operation count to zero for the selected substation bus and the feeders on the substation bus. In addition, it resets the daily operation count and total operation count to zero for all of the cap banks on the substation bus.
Verify All Banks - verifies the status of all cap banks on the selected substation bus.

i2Indent2.wp:style: display: block; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; margin-bottom: 3pt; margin-left: 36pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-top: 0pt; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0pt; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp:Content.i2Indent2: The verify process selects one bank per Feeder or Substation Bus. A command is then sent to the Cap Bank to change its state to the opposite of the currently known state. The current Feeder VARs or Substation Bus VARs are used to track the change. Confirmation occurs using a minimum confirm percent of the VAR success value. The Cap Control system waits for the maximum confirm time, unless the expected change occurs sooner. If the VAR change occurs, then the Cap Bank's confirmed state is internally recorded in the database. A command is then sent to change the bank back to its original state and the confirm process followed again.

i2Indent2.wp:style: display: block; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; margin-bottom: 3pt; margin-left: 36pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-top: 0pt; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0pt; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp:Content.i2Indent2: If the Cap Bank does not confirm on the initial control, then it is assumed that the bank was in the opposite state. A command is sent to the cap bank again to change the state and the confirm process followed again. If the cap bank is confirmed then a command is sent to change the cap bank back to its original state and the confirm process followed again.

i2Indent2.wp:style: display: block; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; margin-bottom: 3pt; margin-left: 36pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-top: 0pt; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0pt; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp:Content.i2Indent2: If none of the commands are confirmed, the bank state is changed to Open Failed or Closed Failed depending on the last command that was sent. If the bank is confirmed then the bank status is changed to the confirmed state.

i2Indent2.wp:style: display: block; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; margin-bottom: 3pt; margin-left: 36pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-top: 0pt; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0pt; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp:Content.i2Indent2: The next cap bank is then selected and the same process is followed until all of the cap banks are validated.
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Verify Failed and Questionable Banks - verifies the status of all failed and questionable cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify Failed Banks - verifies the status of all failed cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify Questionable Banks - verifies the status of questionable cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify Standalone Banks - verifies the status of stand alone cap banks on the selected substation bus.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE The substation bus is disabled when a verification command is executed. When the verification command completes, the substation bus is reneabled.
wp:Content.boBody: If a manual verification or a scheduled verification is running, the following command appears in the commands list:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Verify Stop - stops the verification of cap banks on the selected substation bus.
wp:Content.h1Heading1: 2.5. Substation Bus, Feeders, and Capacitor Banks
wp:Content.boBody: To display detailed information about the feeders and capacitor banks assigned to a substation bus, click on the name of a substation bus.
To view additional information about the selected substation bus, click the + next to the name of the substation bus.

The following information is displayed:
Table 2.3 Substation Bus Information
Column
Meaning
Area
Name of the geographical area of the substation bus.
Control Method
Type of control and control algorithm for the substation bus.
VAR Point
VAR point on the cap control system assigned to the substation bus.
Watt Point
Watt point on the cap control system assigned to the substation bus.
Volt Point
Voltage point on the cap control system assigned to the substation bus.

The following information is displayed about feeders:
Table 2.4 Feeder Information
Column
Meaning
Feeder Name
Name for the feeder.
State
Operational status of the feeder.
Target
If the control algorithm is kVAR, this is the target VAR range.
If the control algorithm is Power Factor, this is the target power factor.
If the control algorithm is Multi Volt, Volts, or Multi Volt VAR, this is the target voltage range.
VAR Load / Est.
VAR Load is the current VAR value on the feeder. Est. is an estimate of what the VAR Load would be if no cap banks were on (closed).1
Date/Time
Date and time of the last feeder data received.
PFactor / Est.
PFactor is the current power factor on the feeder.
Est. is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were closed.
Watts/Volts
Watts and voltage reading of the feeder.a
Daily / Max Ops
Daily total operation count and maximum allowed operation count for all of the cap banks on the feeder.
1If the value is followed by a red (*), the quality of the value is considered not normal. The Cap Control application ignores this value if the Cap Control Ignore Not Normal master config parameter is set to true. By default, this parameter is set to false and the Cap Control application accepts values if the quality is not normal.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Disable Feeder/Enable Feeder - disables or enables the selected feeder.

Reset Op Counts - resets the daily operation count to zero for the selected feeder. In addition, it resets the daily operation count and total operation count to zero for all of the cap banks on the feeder.
wp:Content.boBody:
The following information is displayed about cap banks:
Table 2.5 Cap Bank Information
Column
Meaning
CBC Name
Name of the CBC attached to the cap bank.
CB Name (Order)
Name of the cap bank and the order the cap banks are closed/opened.
State
Operational status of the cap bank.
If a two-way CBC is attached to the cap bank and the two-way CBC did not accept a control command, the reason the CBC did not accept the command is displayed below the cap bank status. For example, if a two-way CBC is in Local Mode and a command is sent to the CBC, the text LOCAL MODE appears below the cap bank status.
Bank Address
Geographical location or street address of the cap bank.
Date/Time
Date and time of the last cap bank data received.
Bank Size
Size of the cap bank in kVAR.
Parent Feeder
Feeder to which the capacitor bank is assigned. The cap banks on all of the feeders are displayed by default. To display the cap banks on a single feeder, select the feeder from the drop-down list.
Daily/Total Op
Daily and total operation counts for the cap bank.
To send a field command to a cap bank, place the mouse cursor over the name of the cap bank and select one of the following commands:
wp:Content.buBullet: Confirm - confirms that the status the cap bank matches the status stored in the Yukon database. For example, if the cap bank status is open, the system sends an open command to the cap bank controller.

boBold.wp:style: display: inline; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; text-decoration: none; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp.wp:style: display: inline; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

buBullet.wp: - sends an open command to the CBC assigned to the cap bank.

wp:Content.buBullet: Close Capacitor - sends a close command to the CBC assigned to the cap bank.

Init Scan - initiates a scan of a two-way CBC assigned to a cap bank. To view the result of the scan, click on the magnifying glass that appears next to the Cap Bank name and refer to "Two-Way CBC Points" on page 61.
Enable OV/UV - enables Over Voltage/Under Voltage (OV/UV) detection on the CBC assigned to the cap bank, if the cbc_allow_ovuv login group property is enabled.
Disable OV/UV - disables Over Voltage/Under Voltage (OV/UV) detection on the CBC assigned to the cap bank, if the cbc_allow_ovuv login group property is enabled.
Flip - Sends a flip command to the CBC assigned to the cap bank. Visible only for a CBC 7010, CBC 7011, or CBC 7012 and only if the Show Flip Command login group property is enabled.
wp:Content.boBody: System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.buBullet: Disable Cap Bank/Enable Cap Bank - disables or enables a cap bank.
Reset Op Counts - sets the total operation count of the selected cap bank to the value entered in the Op Count text box.
wp:Content.boBody: To change the cap bank state stored in the Yukon database, select a new state from Cap Bank list:
wp:Content.buBullet: Open - sets the cap bank state to opened.
Close - sets the cap bank state to closed.
OpenQuestionable - sets the cap bank state to opened questionable.
CloseQuestionable - sets the cap bank state to closed questionable.
OpenFail - sets the cap bank state to opened failed.
CloseFail - sets the cap bank state to closed failed.
OpenPending - sets the cap bank state to opened pending.
ClosePending - sets the cap bank state to closed pending.
wp:Content.boBody: To reset the total operation count of a Capacitor Bank:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Place the mouse cursor over the State value of a Cap Bank or click on the State value of a Cap Bank and select Reset Op Counts.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: An Op Count Value column appears to the right of the State column.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a new total operation count in the Op Count Value text box.

wp.wp:style: display: inline; color: #000000; font-style: italic; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

i1Indent1.wp: If the Op Count Value text box is left blank, the operation count will be reset to zero.

wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Reset to set the total operation count to the value in the Op Count Value text box.
wp:Content.boBody: If a two-way CBC is attached to a Cap Bank, a magnifying glass appears next to the Cap Bank name. To view a list of CBC points including the current value and timestamp, click the magnifying glass.
If the Show Cap Bank Add Info login group property is enabled, an x appears next the Cap Bank name. To view additional information about a cap bank, click on the x.
To temporarily move a cap bank from its parent feeder to another feeder:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on the name of the cap bank's current parent feeder to move the cap bank.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click the + next to a substation bus to display the feeders assigned to the sub bus.
Enter a new control order for the cap bank in the New Control Order text box.
Click on the name of a feeder to temporarily move the cap bank to that feeder.
Click the Close button to close the Cap Bank Temp Move window.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: After a cap bank has been temporarily moved, the parent feeder for that cap bank appears in orange text.
wp:Content.boBody: To move a cap bank back to its original parent feeder:
wp:Content.s1Step1:
Place the mouse cursor over the name of the parent feeder for the moved cap bank.
The parent feeder's name appears in orange text.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click on the Temp Move Back link to move the cap bank back to its original parent feeder.
wp:Content.boBody: The Web-based capacitor control client allows you to view analysis reports of capacitor control data.
To view an analysis report of today's kVAR and Watt values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have kVAR and Watt points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click Today kVAR/Watt to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view an analysis report of today's power factor values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have power factor points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click Today PF to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view an analysis report of the past 30 day's kVAR and Watt values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have kVAR and Watt points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click 30 Day kVAR/Watt to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view an analysis report of the past 30 day's power factor values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have power factor points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click 30 Day PF to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: The Web-based capacitor control client allows you to view orphaned devices or devices that have not been assigned to parent devices.
To view substations that have not been assigned to a substation area, click View and then select Orphaned Substations.
To view feeders that have not been assigned to a substation bus, click View and then select Orphaned Feeders.
To view capacitor banks that have not been assigned to a feeder, click View and then select Orphaned CapBanks.
To view CBCs that have not been assigned to a capacitor bank, click View and then select Orphaned CBCs.
The Web-based capacitor control client allows you to view schedules that can be assigned to substation buses to control when cap bank verification commands are sent.
To view the cap control schedules, click on the View menu and then select Schedules.

The following schedule information can be viewed and edited on this page:
Table 2.6 Schedule Information
Column
Meaning
Name
Name of the schedule.
Next Run Time
The date and time the schedule will run.
Last Run Time
The date and time the schedule last ran.
Interval
How often the schedule runs.
Disabled
Displays if the schedule is disabled from running.
(Edit)
To edit a schedule, click the (Edit) button.
Delete
To delete a schedule, click the Delete button.
The Web-based capacitor control client allows you to view schedules that can be assigned to substation buses to control when cap bank verification commands are sent.
To view the cap control strategies, click on the View menu and then select Strategies.

The following schedule information can be viewed and edited on this page:
Table 2.7 Strategy Information
Column
Meaning
Strategy Name
Name of the cap control strategy.
(Edit)
To edit a strategy, click the (Edit) button.
Delete
To delete a strategy, click the Delete button.
The one-line diagram is a graphical representation of a substation bus, feeders, and cap banks.
To view a one-line:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select a substation bus to display as a one-line diagram.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click View.
Click One-Line to display the one-line diagram.
wp:Content.boBody: The colors of the lines in the one-line diagram represent the status of the substation bus and feeders.
wp:Content.buBullet: Blue - This substation bus or feeder is enabled.
Gray - The substation bus or feeder is disabled.
Yellow - There is a pending action occurring on the substation bus or feeder.
wp:Content.boBody:
To exit a one-line, click on the exit icon
located in the lower left-hand corner of the page.

To regenerate a one-line after making changes to the Capacitor Control role properties, click on the regenerate icon
located in the lower left-hand corner of the page.
The following information about the substation bus appears below the Cap Control logo:

Table 2.8 Substation Bus Information
Text
Meaning
(name)
Name of the substation bus.
Target
If the control algorithm is kVAR, this is the target VAR range.
If the control algorithm is Power Factor, this is the target power factor.
If the control algorithm is Multi Volt, Volts, or Multi Volt VAR, this is the target voltage range.
VAR Load
VAR Load is the current VAR value on the substation bus.1
Watts
Watts displays the wattage reading of the substation bus.a
Volts
Volts displays the voltage reading of the substation bus.a
Est.VAR Load
Est. is an estimate of what the VAR Load would be if no cap banks were on (closed).
PF
PF is the current power factor on the substation bus.
Est.PF
Est. PF is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were on (closed).
Daily Ops
Daily is the daily total operation count for all of the cap banks on the substation bus.
Max Daily Ops
Max Ops is a user-defined maximum number of daily cap bank operations.
T:
Tag/Disable status of the substation bus. A D indicates a disabled sub bus.
1If the value is followed by a red (*), the quality of the value is considered not normal. The Cap Control application ignores this value if the Cap Control Ignore Not Normal master config parameter is set to true. By default, this parameter is set to false and the Cap Control application accepts values even if the quality is not normal.
The substation bus is represented by an image located below the substation information. The appearance of the substation bus image changes depending on the operational state of the substation.

To display the Substation Bus Editor, click on the notepad icon
located to the right of the substation bus image.
To display the available substation bus commands, click on the substation bus image.

To reset the daily operation count to zero for the substation bus and feeders and reset the daily operation count and total operation count to zero for all of the cap banks on the substation bus, click the Reset OpCount button.

To confirm that the status of each cap bank on the substation bus matches the status stored in the Yukon database, click the Confirm All button. For example, if the cap bank status is open, the system sends an open command to the cap bank controller.
To verify the status of cap banks on the substation bus by sending a series of open and close commands to the cap bank controllers:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select one of the following cap bank verification options.
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Verify All Banks - verifies the status of all cap banks on the substation bus.
Verify Failed and Questionable Banks - verifies the status of all failed and questionable cap banks on the substation bus.
Verify Failed Banks - verifies the status of all failed cap banks on the substation bus.
Verify Questionable Banks - verifies the status of questionable cap banks on the substation bus.
Verify Standalone Banks - verifies the status of stand alone cap banks on the substation bus.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Execute to start the selected cap bank verification.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: If a manual verification or a scheduled verification is running, the following command appears in the commands list:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Verify Stop - stops the verification of cap banks on the substation bus.
wp:Content.boBody: The T: located above the substation bus image displays the tag/disable status of the sub bus.
Disabling a substation bus prevents the Yukon server from using that substation. This is useful if maintenance is being performed on cap banks located on the sub bus.
To disable the substation bus and tag it:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on the T:. The following tag window appears.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the Disable check box and enter the reason for disable the substation in the Reason text box.
Click Execute.
Click OK to disable the substation and tag it with the text entered in the Reason text box.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE The substation bus is automatically disabled when a verification command is run. When the verification command completes, the substation bus is reneabled.
wp:Content.boBody: The following information is displayed about each feeder on the substation bus:

Table 2.9 Feeder Information
Text
Meaning
T:
Tag/Disable status of the feeder. A D indicates a disabled feeder.
(name)
Name of the feeder.
kVAR
Displays the current VAR value on the feeder and an estimate of what the VAR Load would be if no cap banks were on (closed).1
Watt
Displays the wattage reading of the feeder.
Volt
Displays the voltage reading of the feeder.
PF
Displays the current power factor on the feeder and an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were on (closed).
Daily Ops
Displays the daily total operation count for all of the cap banks on the feeder and a user-defined maximum number of cap bank operations.
1If the value is followed by a red (*), the quality of the value is considered not normal. The Cap Control application ignores this value if the Cap Control Ignore Not Normal master config parameter is set to true. By default, this parameter is set to false and the Cap Control application accepts values even if the quality is not normal.
To display the Feeder Editor, click on the notepad icon
located to the right of the feeder name.
To display the available feeder commands, click on the name of a feeder.

To reset the daily operation count to zero for the selected feeder and reset the daily operation count and total operation count to zero for all of the cap banks on the feeder, click the Reset OpCount button.
The T: located above the name of each feeder displays the tag/disable status of the sub bus.
Disabling a feeder prevents the Yukon server from using that feeder. This is useful if maintenance is being performed on cap banks located on the feeder.
To disable a feeder and tag it:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on the T:. The following tag window appears.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the Disable check box and enter the reason for disable the feeder in the Reason text box.
Click Execute.
Click OK to disable the feeder and tag it with the text entered in the Reason text box.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE The feeder is automatically disabled when a verification command is run. When the verification command completes, the feeder is reneabled.
wp:Content.boBody: The following information is displayed about each capacitor bank on the substation bus:

Table 2.10 Feeder Information
Text
Meaning
(name)
Name of the cap bank.
T:-:-:-
Displays the disable statuses of the cap bank.
D - Cap bank is disabled.
V - Over Voltage/Under Voltage (OV/UV) detection is disabled on the CBC assigned to the cap bank.
S - StandAlone cap bank.
Ops Count
Daily operation count for the cap bank.
Bank Size
Size of the cap bank in kVAR.
CBC
Name of the Cap Bank Controller assigned to the cap bank.
Each cap bank is represented by an image as show in the graphic below. The appearance of the cap bank image changes depending on the operational state of the cap bank

To display the Capacitor Bank Editor, click on the notepad icon
located to the right of the feeder name.

To display additional information about the CBC that is attached to a Cap Bank, click the question mark icon
located to the left of the cap bank image.

If a two-way CBC is attached to the Cap Bank, a magnifying glass icon
appears below the question mark icon. To view a list of CBC points including the current value and timestamp, click the magnifying glass.
To display the available cap bank commands, click on the cap bank image.
To send an open command the CBC assigned to the cap bank, click the Open button.
To send an close command the CBC assigned to the cap bank, click the Close button.

To confirm that the status the cap bank matches the status stored in the Yukon database, click the Confirm button. For example, if the cap bank status is open, the system sends an open command to the cap bank controller.
To send a maintenance command to the CBC assigned to the cap bank, click the Maintenance link and select one of the following commands:
wp:Content.buBullet: Scan - initiates a scan of a two-way CBC assigned to a cap bank.
Enable OV/UV - enables Over Voltage/Under Voltage (OV/UV) detection on the CBC assigned to the cap bank.
wp:Content.boBody: To send a database change command to the Yukon system, click the DB Change link and select one of the following:
To set the total operation count for the cap bank, click the Reset OpCount check box, enter a new value for the total operation count in the text box and click OK.
To change the cap bank state stored in the Yukon database, select a new state from the drop-down list:
wp:Content.buBullet: Open - sets the cap bank state to opened.
Close - sets the cap bank state to closed.
OpenQuestionable - sets the cap bank state to opened questionable.
CloseQuestionable - sets the cap bank state to closed questionable.
OpenFail - sets the cap bank state to opened failed.
CloseFail - sets the cap bank state to closed failed.
OpenPending - sets the cap bank state to opened pending.
ClosePending - sets the cap bank state to closed pending.
wp:Content.boBody: To view a list of the recent cap bank controls:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select one or more substation buses, feeders, or cap banks for which to view recent controls.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click View.
Click Recent Controls to display the list.
wp:Content.boBody: To view a list of cap bank that are assigned to a feeder other than the original feeder:
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Cap Bank Moves to display the report.
